ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class have given me a better understanding of Spanish vocabulary, grammar, speaking, and writing.
I learned new Spanish vocabulary, new grammatical techniques, and many cultural aspects of Hispanic culture.
I practice reading, writing and speaking Spanish more so than I ever have.
I learned how to have more fluid conversations with native Spanish speakers, as well as more complex grammatical rules of the Spanish language.
By practicing Spanish each and every day, I grew to become much more confident in my class abilities. I enjoyed the versatility of the class and developed a much better Spanish vocabulary.
I feel like I progressed significantly in just a semester of taking Spanish II. I feel very well prepared for the next level.
Grammar and speaking skills for Spanish. Different verb forms and sentence structures for conversational Spanish.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: not too hard, great introductory language class to take if you have some background in high school Spanish, solid curriculum, and great teachers. 
Weakness: sometimes the class moved a little slowly.
Strengths: Professor was great and very understanding. I feel like I have become a better Spanish listener and speaker by taking this course. Weakness: Directions for assignments were often unclear.

This course moves very quickly, and I think that students could benefit from covering less topics more in depth. Also, the umbrella site was not very well organized and oftentimes assignments were not communicated to students (they were just expected to know about them).

Profesora Reymundi is so kind and truly wants her students to succeed!  I felt like there was a lot of time in between exams, which was good, but I felt that by the time we were tested it wasn't as fresh in my mind.
I thought this class was great. At first it was tricky with the masks, but then the professor switched to a clear mask which really helped.

I think that the course requires a lot of outside independent work, which Prof. Reymundi made clear from the first day of class. As a result, students that practice on their own (and really, with their own material) will do the best. This was both a good and bad thing in my case, but something that ultimately really impacted one's ability to both enjoy and participate in class.

The course was not very well organized. The syllabus was new so that explains most of it but the instructions should have been better clarified. It would also be useful if canvas was organized better (i.e. all the information for each assignment being posted in the "assignments" tab rather than the modules.
Making attendance mandatory in a pandemic is ridiculous.

Lots of speaking and listening improved my conversational Spanish skills. I also improved my grasp on certain grammar rules. 

No clear weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely. This class was great. I knew some Spanish going into this class (as it is L2) and I had a lot of fun with it and learned a lot.
I would recommend this course to a student looking to learn the Spanish language and complete the language requirement.
Yes, because of Profesora Reymundi.
Yes
Yes, it was a great transition from Spanish 110 and definitely improved my ability to both speak, write, and read in Spanish.

I would recommend Spanish to other students as it is so important, and also because I thought that Prof. Reymundi was fantastic. That being said, the workload in Spanish was almost always the highest compared to my other classes, and often impacted my ability to put as much time and effort as I'd like into classes that I knew would go toward my field of study.
Yes! It seems to be taught very well and is very well organized.
No, but I guess we have to take it.
Yes.
